text:
December 8, 1960
Dr. Harry J. Skornia
1015 West Church Street
Champaign, Illinois
Dear Harry:
During my recent visit to New York In connection with LRI
Board meeting, I arranged to have a chat with Arno Huth.
He had recently returned from a tour of Africa as a consult¬
ant to the State Department and Winfield thought it would
be useful to talk with him. It was.
He was able to fill in some of the gaps in my knowledge of
the social and political complexity of the Sudan and had
valuable suggestions on procedures and approaches. His
list of things not to do was, perhaps, even more invaluable.
He said that he had had a letter from you last summer making
reference to a possible role he might play in NAEB affairs
and wondered if I knew to what you alluded. I suggested that
you might have been thinking of the Sudan contract, but he
did not think this wa3 the case. I said that I would write
and ask you — which I have now done.
The Sudan Radio Contract is all but signed and sealed (I
expect a call this week for the final session) and, I under¬
stand, the pressures are really building up from the Sudanese,
for action. I am especially encouraged by the likelihood
that we will be able to get Sid Head to be the program man.
He is actively interested and is now negotiating with his
administration to see if he can be freed.
I had lunch two weeks ago with Paul Shinkman and Jewell
and I were invited to their Georgetown home for dinner
last Saturday evening. He is very much interested in our
news project and vastly intrigued by the Lasswell "clarifier"
